segments.text: Alright team, EVA briefing for tomorrow's antenna repair mission. Lieutenant Torres, Flight Engineer Kim, you're suited up.
Ready to go. I've reviewed the repair procedures three times. The S-band antenna has a loose mounting bracket.
I've got the replacement parts staged in the airlock. Two spare brackets and the torque wrench calibrated to spec.
Good. Let's walk through the timeline. Depressurization starts at 0800. You'll exit the airlock at approximately 0845.
The antenna is on the Z1 truss segment, correct? That's about 30 meters from the airlock.
Correct. You'll translate along the starboard side using the handrails. Kim, you're on tether management.
Understood. I'll make sure we stay properly tethered at all times. Safety locks every three meters.
Once you reach the antenna, Torres will perform the bracket removal. Kim documents with helmet cam footage.
The old bracket has four bolts. I'll remove them counterclockwise, bag them so nothing floats away.
I'll have the waste bag ready. We can't afford to create orbital debris from loose hardware.
Ground control estimates 45 minutes for the entire repair. That puts you back inside by 1030 at the latest.
What's the backup plan if the bracket is more damaged than we expect?
We have authorization to remove the antenna entirely and bring it inside for full assessment. That would extend the EVA to two hours.
Our suits are rated for seven hours, so we have plenty of margin. But let's hope the simple fix works.
Agreed. Now, environmental conditions. We'll be in sunlight for the first 30 minutes, then eclipse for 15.
That temperature swing is significant. Plus 120 Celsius in sun, minus 150 in shadow.
Your suit thermal control systems will handle it, but be aware of the transition. Don't rush during eclipse.
We'll use helmet lights in shadow. I've already checked the batteries, full charge.
Excellent preparation. Communication protocol: you'll be on UHF with me as CAPCOM. Ground has the S-band backup.
If we lose comm with you, we abort and return to airlock immediately. No exceptions.
Correct. Safety is paramount. No heroics. If anything feels wrong, you come back inside.
Understood, Commander. What about the suit integrity checks tonight?
We'll do full suit pressure checks at 2000 hours. I want both suits at 4.3 PSI for 30 minutes, zero leaks.
And the prebreathe protocol starts at 0700 tomorrow, one hour before depressurization.
Exactly. Pure oxygen to purge nitrogen from your bloodstream. Prevents decompression sickness.
I've done this before, but it never gets routine. There's always that moment stepping outside where you think, 'This is really happening.'
My first EVA, I was terrified. Now I just focus on the checklist and trust my training.
That's the right mindset. Fear keeps you sharp, but training keeps you alive. You both are ready for this.
Thanks, Commander. Any other concerns or special instructions from ground control?
They want extra photos of the solar array while you're out there. We've noticed some degradation on panel 2B.
We can get those on the translation back. That panel is near our return path.
Perfect. Alright, any questions? This is the time to ask.
I think we're good. We've got this.

environment.background_sounds: ventilation system, equipment beeping, papers rustling
